frameDefinitions: Two or more distinct entities, which may be concrete or abstract objects or types, are characterized as being similar to each other.
These words refer to separating a Whole into Parts, or separating one part from another.

A Phenomenon is portrayed with respect to the Degree of likelihood that it will  be perceived and known, given the (usually implicit) Evidence, Perceiver, and the Circumstances in which it is considered.
In this class of perception words, a Phenomenon, typically expressed as External Argument, and its perceptual characteristics are given some description.
This frame concerns a specific subset of Instances of a Type which are evaluated in terms of their similarity to a conceptual prototype of the Type.
frameExamples:
A mulberry is very <t>similar</t> in shape
to a loganberry
I <t>divided</t> the class into groups in alphabetical order .
It's abundantly <t>obvious</t> that we'll need to spend more time on public perception.
There's a hamburger bar open, and it <t>smells</t> real good.
Kim has a <t>different</t> hair color every week
listRoleDefinitions: This role marks constituents that express the set of objects or types whose similarity is at issue.

When there is an asymmetry, <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the entity characterized by its similarity to <fen>Entity_2</fen>, whose characteristics are assumed to be known.  <fen>Entity_1</fen> is often an external argument.

When the <fen>Entities</fen> are expressed separately, <fen>Entity_2</fen> is the one whose characteristics are assumed to be known; it serves as a basis for establishing characteristics of <fen>Entity_1</fen>.
This role marks constituents which express a property in respect to which the similarity of the entities is assessed.
A fact about <fen>Entity_1</fen> or the <fen>Entities</fen> that reveals how <fen>Entity_1</fen> is the same or different from other entities.  (Note the contrast with 'as to'.)
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the similarity occurs or exists.
The Place is the general area in which similarity occurs or exists
The <fen>Whole</fen> is a single entity or an aggregate of entities which is separated into <fen>Parts</fen>.  It is usually the NP Object of a target verb.
This refers collectively to the Parts resulting from separation of a Whole:
Part-1 is the first of two Parts mentioned. This is most often the Object of a verb.
<fen>Part_2</fen> is the second of two <fen>Parts</fen> mentioned. This is usually a PP Complement. First,
With causative uses of these verbs, an Agent separates or divides something.  The Agent is usually expressed as the External Argument:
The <fen>Cause</fen> is the non-agent that brings about the separation.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the separation occurs.
Where the separation occurs.
The entity or facts that are undeniable given the <fen>Evidence</fen>.
The gradable aspect of a <fen>Phenomenon</fen> which concerns how likely it is that the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> be known. This frame element is incorporated by the lexical units in this frame.
A modifier expressing  the deviation of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> from the norm or from the value for another <fen>Phenomenon</fen> in terms of how likely the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> would be known.
The <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is obvious
The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is typically the External Argument of the verbs in this frame.
<fen>Characterization</fen> is the subjective description (of the <fen>Perceiver_passive</fen> ) of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<fen>Appraisal</fen> is the positive or negative judgement given to the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.

<fen>Inference</fen> expresses some property of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> that is not a direct  feature of the particular sensory modality (if any), but rather is based on perception within that modality.
The kind of thing of which instances are under discussion.
The instance of the <fen>Type</fen> that is currently under discussion.
An instance of the <fen>Type</fen> that was encountered previously and which is now compared for identity with the <fen>Current_instance</fen>.
The situation in which another instance of the <fen>Type</fen> was encountered earlier.
The complete set of instances of the <fen>Type</fen> involved in the mentioned contexts.
The Time when the Current_instance is the same or different.
A thing or episode that is considered exemplary of a certain <fen>Type</fen>.
The category of things or events from which an <fen>Instance</fen> is picked out.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The two painters</fex> were alike in being unable to draw acceptably .
In the first phase <fex>Barthes's approach</fex> has similarities to that of Levi-Strauss.
The results of Method 2 show remarkable similarity <fex>to those obtained by Method 1</fex>
The disc announced Friday is <fex>physically</fex> similar to current music CDs
His presidency was different <fex>in that it offered a way forward for the common man</fex> .
The directors split <fex>the company</fex> in two.
The directors split the company <fex>in two</fex>.
First, separate <fex>the yolks</fex> from the whites.
separate the yolks <fex>from the whites</fex>.
<fex>The researcher</fex> divided subjects into groups.
I divided the prize money among the winners <fex>that night</fex>.
You should separate the yolks from the whites <fex>over the sink</fex>.
It is obvious for example <fex>that 9/10 is not the same as 1</fex>.
It is <fex>abundantly</fex> obvious you have not a clue how the Retro Program works.
It is obvious <fex>now</fex> that Senator O. T. Tawa has no plan.
<fex>The soup</fex> tasted very salty.
Kim's new furniture looks <fex>sort of bluish</fex>.
Kim's hair feels <fex>nice</fex>.
Pat sounds <fex>devastated</fex> by the bad news.
Smithers works in a different <fex>office</fex> now
This is a different car <fex>than last week</fex>
Kent Clark and Superman are the same person

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Islamic Society for the Promotion of Religious Tolerance
